item.name: Maximum number of opened files
item.description: It could be increased by using sysctrl utility or modifying file /etc/sysctl.conf.

item.name: Maximum number of processes
item.description: It could be increased by using sysctrl utility or modifying file /etc/sysctl.conf.

item.name: Number of processes
item.description: Total number of processes in any state.

item.name: Processor load (1 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: Processor load (5 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: Processor load (15 min average per core)
item.description: The processor load is calculates as system CPU load divided by number of CPU cores.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent doing nothing.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing hardware interrupts.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: Amount of time the CPU has been waiting for I/O to complete.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' proccess that have been niced.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The amount of time the CPU has been servicing software interrupts.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The amount of CPU 'stolen' from this virtual machine by the hypervisor for other tasks (such as running another virtual machine).

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running the kernel and its processes.

item.name: CPU $2 time
item.description: The time the CPU has spent running users' processes that are not niced.

item.name: Number of winbind socket connections
item.key: system.run[/usr/sbin/ss -x -o state established src /var/lib/samba/winbindd_privileged/pipe | grep -c u_str]

item.name: System information
item.description: The information as normally returned by 'uname -a'.

item.name: Number of logged in users
item.description: Number of users who are currently logged in.

item.name: Available memory
item.description: Available memory is defined as free+cached+buffers memory.

item_prototype.name: Bytes Read per second {#BLKDEV}
item_prototype.description:
Bytes read by device per second. Zabbix only supports sectors per second [1] but can be converted to bytes by multiplying by 512 as there are 512 byte in a sector by default on Linux [2]
[1] https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/2.2/manual/appendix/items/supported_by_platform [2] https://support.zabbix.com/browse/ZBXNEXT-1914

item_prototype.name: Bytes Written per second {#BLKDEV}
item_prototype.description:
Bytes written by device per second. Zabbix only supports sectors per second [1] but can be converted to bytes by multiplying by 512 as there are 512 byte in a sector by default on Linux [2]
[1] https://www.zabbix.com/documentation/2.2/manual/appendix/items/supported_by_platform [2] https://support.zabbix.com/browse/ZBXNEXT-1914

discovery_rule.name: Network interface discovery
discovery_rule.description: Discovery of network interfaces as defined in global regular expression "Network interfaces for discovery".

item_prototype.name: Network Interface Frame Error Percentage on {#IFNAME}
Network interface total packets received on {#IFNAME}
Network Interface RX Dropped Count on {#IFNAME}
Network interface Received CRC Error Count on {#IFNAME}

trigger_prototype.name: Configured Network Speed is less than 1Gbps on {#IFNAME}
Frame Errors percentage is greater than {$FRAME_ERROR_PERCENT} on {#IFNAME}

item_prototype.name: Network Interface Frame Error Percentage on {#BIFNAME}
Network Interface Total Packets Received on {#BIFNAME}
Network Interface RX Error Count on {#BIFNAME}
Network Interface RX Dropped Count on {#BIFNAME}
Network Interface TX Error Count on {#BIFNAME}
Network Interface TX Dropped Count on {#BIFNAME}
Network interface Received CRC Error Count on {#BIFNAME}

trigger_prototype.name: Frame Errors percentage is greater than {$FRAME_ERROR_PERCENT} on {#BIFNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than {$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}
Free disk space is less than {$DISK_DISASTER_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_DISASTER_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than {$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.size[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_WARN_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free disk space is less than {$DISK_WARN_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free inodes is less than {$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}
Free inodes is less than {$DISK_DISASTER_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_DISASTER_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free inodes is less than {$DISK_HIGH_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger_prototype.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}>({$DISK_AVERAGE_PERCENT}-1) and {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:vfs.fs.inode[{#FSNAME},pfree].last(0)}<{$DISK_WARN_PERCENT}
trigger_prototype.name: Free inodes is less than {$DISK_WARN_PERCENT}% on {#FSNAME}

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:system.run[/usr/sbin/ss -x -o state established src /var/lib/samba/winbindd_privileged/pipe | grep -c u_str].last(0)}>150
trigger.name: Active winbind connections is over 150
trigger.description: The number of active winbind connections is over 150. This generally indicates an issue with Active Directory. Winbind will stop accepting new queries when this hits 200.

trigger.name: Configured max number of opened files is too low
Disk I/O is overloaded
trigger.description: OS spends significant time waiting for I/O (input/output) operations. It could be indicator of performance issues with storage system.

trigger.name: Khugepaged defragmentation is enabled
trigger.description:
Run the below command to resolve
echo never > /sys/kernel/mm/redhat_transparent_hugepage/defrag

trigger.name: Lack of free swap space ( <{$SWAP_AVERAGE_PERCENT}% )
trigger.description: It probably means that the systems requires more physical memory.

trigger.name: Lack of free swap space ( <{$SWAP_WARN_PERCENT}% )
trigger.description: It probably means that the systems requires more physical memory.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:system.run[/usr/sbin/ss -x -o state established src /var/lib/samba/winbindd_privileged/pipe | grep -c u_str].max(86400)}>100
trigger.name: Max winbind connections is over 100
trigger.description: The maximum number of winbind connections over the last day is over the threshold of 100. This may indicate an underlying problem with active directory.

trigger.expression: {Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:proc.num[].last(0)}>({Template OS Linux Hadoop 1.8.0:kernel.maxproc.last(0)}*0.90)
trigger.name: Too many processes
